comment: I can't believe a game this terrible is in the top 100 on BGG. Agricola is a long and tedious game with zero fun. I wish I could give a rating lower than 1, perhaps negative-infinity? The absolute worst part in this game is having to feed your workers... talk about a complete waste of time that just drags out an already tedious game. It's soooo punishing not to feed your workers that I can't imagine anyone choosing to not feed their workers or accidentally forgetting to feed their workers. Which means that if everyone is essentially forced to divert a significant amount of workers just to gather food all accomplishing the same thing every turn, then it is a pointless waste of time added to a pitifully long and boring game. That's like making a rule that says "you have 7 workers to place, but each round you must discard 4 of your workers and only use the remaining 3... But you can't just discard the 4 workers, you need to spend 15 minutes per worker you discard trying to figure out the most optimal way to discard each worker..." Blegh,...
:angyface: :axe:
No interaction / Multiplayer Solitaire

The narrative of the game is cute. It just feels weird how much the game has to encourage you to do a variety of tasks (instead of just one) by altering the points. It's barely okay, but the advanced modes with all the special cards kinda kills it for me, and that's how everyone insists on playing it now anyway.

I despise this game. All the excitement of watching paint dry. I have never disliked playing a board game as much as this one. I like Euro-games, but this game is mind-numbing, and the theme is dull. Please, stay away from the game. PLEASE.

I'm a gamer's gamer. Been boardgaming and wargaming as a hobby since 1969. I love Euros and wargames. I should like this one. Nope. Never again. Awful. Brutal, nasty, cut-throat, passive-aggressive bullshit, stressful, un-fun.

I'd rather undergo root canal work ... without freezing. I'd rather spend three hours in a quiet, dark corner poking myself in the eye with a dull pencil or rusty spoon while listening to Donny and Marie music. I would not play this game again even if you offered me US$1,000 (really). I'd rather play Candyland.

Technically, I should rate it a "1.1" since my opinion of the game somewhat matches BGG rating system definition for a "2" ... Extremely annoying game, won't ever play this again. It's much closer to the definition of a "1" rating though, however it's not fully "broken" as a "1" rating requires (though the uneven luck-of-the-draw cards and absolute blocking mechanic [especially when this is done purely for spiteful reasons] pretty much do make it broken in my opinion, since there is no way to recover from these two things). But both of the other two requirements for a 1 rating certainly hold true ... Defies description of a game. You won't catch me dead playing this. Since I agree with two of the three criteria a 1 requires, a 1 is what it rates.

Agricola is the only boardgame I've ever quit half-way through a game (my fourth game, so three-and-a-half plays suffered through) because I was so crazy bored and stupidly frustrated with the absolute choice denial blocking mechanic and the ungodly slow pace and length this game takes. It's also a much meaner game than most of it's fans will acknowledge despite it's friendly little veneer, and it's a game that railroads you to having to do something with little variation in your choice of what to do. Any game that encourages the sort of behaviour where players yell out "I shall build fences just so you can't!" is nothing but a spiteful mind-fuck of a game, and a lot meaner than I want to play.

Boring as hell. Never again, I can't even stand the sight of the game, honestly.

I have turned down money to play this game again. I hate Agricola that much. I absolutely refuse to ever play this "game" again.

Does it deserve it's high rating? I guess, and I do acknowledge that it is a very good game for many people, but I have no real idea why, since it's the complete opposite of fun in my opinion. Can I honestly and without malice rate it a "1" based on BGG's definition of a what constitutes a 1 or 2 for how I define/rate games? Absolutely.

Here on the Internet, specialized abbreviations are often used as a form of shorthand. The most prevalent occurrence would most likely be LOL, short for laughing out loud. Used as a way of expressing laughter in a medium that is not conducive to auditory feedback, it's a common cue. Another example is IMO, or in my opinion.

Some may believe a falling level of literacy is implied by the habitual use of such quasi-words, but they're really quite handy. Either WTF or POS could be used as a quick way of referring to this game, since they encapsulate the experience in a brief, pithy manner.

Perhaps I should have just started (and ended) this comment with WTF or POS...

How bad is Agricola? Let me bore with a story that best describes it.

When I got back into gaming around 2009, I was exposed to Eurogames. I was an old school wargamer, who had been out of the loop for 25+ years, which had dulled my senses, so I was really digging Euros. I had yet to play any of the revered "top 10" on BGG, and then a well-intentioned soul invited me to play Agricola. Oh goodie, the #2 ranked game!

If you are familiar with Lord of the Rings, I was like King Théoden of Rohan and Euros were like Wormtongue. As I "play" Agricola (and I use "play" generously, as that implies some level of fun), I start waking up and seeing through the haze. This game was terrible. It had about as much to do with farming as Nexus Ops has with ballet.

And unlike other Euros, this one was dragging on. It felt like centuries. It wasn't because of analysis paralysis at the table. It was because this game was accelerating our table to near light speeds and relativistic effects were slowing time to a crawl!

Not wanting to be "that guy" who cuts out on a game, even one that sucks as much as Agricola, I pondered ways to actually leave the game that would be acceptable. I was thinking, "If the Second Coming happened right now, that would be cool." If you remember the old TV commercials, I desperately tried to re-create the magic by saying "Calgon! Take me away!" but alas, I did not transport to a bubble bath. I once pulled out my tri-fold wallet, flipped it open, leaned over and discreetly spoke into it, "Scottie! Beam me up!" hoping against all hope it would actually work.

When the torture was over and the victory points were tallied, I won! No, I did not have the most -- not by a long shot! No, I won because I would never have to be exposed to this game again. The poor folks at the table were still under Wormtongue's influence and would repeat the misery.

Not only was I woke, I was rejuvenated: Agricola tried everything to break me, but I overcame!

Now that I fully understood what "multi-player solitaire" and "themeless abomination" meant, with clarity of thought, I drove home afterward, got on BGG, and lowered the rating of every single Eurogame I ever played, because I saw Euros for what they are. This game is so broken that it broke an entire genre for me! How's that for broken?

I rose a new and better man and embraced the glorious wargames of my youth and their distant cousin, Ameritrash.

I guess I owe a great debt to Agricola. If not for the depths of its suck, I might still be stuck in that beige-colored land of "elegant mechanics" and utter boredom. So thank you Uwe for freeing me from this cage!

I dedicate this rating to everyone who hasn't yet played this game and gave it a 10 based on hype. I wanted to like it; I really did. Heck, I even bought this game after I thought that maybe I was missing all the fun because I didn't play it often enough.

Someone recently asked me if my opinion has changed about Agricola. It hasn't. In fact, it's gotten worse. A one indicates my personal reaction to a game is that I have no desire to play it. Ever. I've played it eight times now, with different groups of players, and each time is worse than the last.

It's way too fiddly and illogical to be entertaining, and the theme of French Medieval farming is, shall we say, uninspiring. What next, a game about simultaneously building wooden, iron, *and* steel ships in a French port while avoiding starvation, Mr. Rosenberg?

Yes, the mechanics of Agricola are interesting, but ultimately, the game as a whole is a dismal failure as fun, which is the primary reason for this rating.

Even though it comes with a shit ton of cards. I rather play monopoly every day. Which says a lot. I prefer my daily work over this dry scripted drag of what they call a game.

And now he's into Tetromino games ... sigh ... I can see he can design good games, he just picks all the things I hate in gaming ;-) To me he approaches everything too much from a programming approach. It's so predictable and dry. It needs more surprise and adventure.

It's too tight for my taste. Everything you try to accomplish takes several workers - and you only start out with two.

Feeding your people is a central part of the game and a real nuisance. There's always a feeling of dread because you don't have time for everything - and because of the way scoring works, you have to do a bit of everything.

Having 14 different cards at the beginning of the game is pretty neat and the best part of the game - but most of the cards you don't even get to make use of. You play maybe 2-4 cards in the course of the game. The way the cards work isn't very streamlined and the return on investment is often very slim. The cards never feel powerful or satisfying to use.

I love the wooden animal meeples, but the art on the cards is atrocious.

I've only played this game 3 times so as usual, take my rating with a grain of salt, but I cannot stand this game. The game isn't bad as far as games go, it just isn't fun for me to play personally. Every single time I develop a strategy, the player before me takes the action space I needed, so there is no strategy, just adaptation. But adaptation usually means you get a worse option and it doesn't synergize well enough for your engine. I recognize fully that I'm losing because I just don't get the game, but playing it is a chore because of how constantly (literally every turn) your preferred option is going to be taken from you. Even in the games where all of my occupations and major/minor improvements are synergizing well with my strategy and I'm somehow managing to get the actions I want, when I want, I still end up trailing behind the leader significantly. The leader had 3 beggar cards in harvest 1 and still beat me by nearly double the points in the end. Game is not for me, and don't feel bad if you feel the same when you play it.

Absolutely fantastic. Wasn't convinced on my first game, scoring only 15 points (how embarrassing). I failed to appreciate how important it is to feed your family and felt pressured all game. However, it has grown on me very quickly. I play Puerto Rico and Power Grid plus a plethora of other games and heartily rate this a 10. Fabulous 2 player game. Fantastic with more. What my gaming club loves is that it plays within 60 - 90 minutes no matter what. There are lots of things to do and you have to have 2 or 3 options up your sleeve. The cards for the different decks are great but you should limit yourself to playing only 2 or 3 as we've found that you tend to waste family member actions on getting them out while other players get ahead by plowing fields, sowing, building fences, etc. Fun.

21Dec10 - Still love this game. What a fantastic 2 player! I like multiplayer too. We have become quite wary of the cards. You really can fall behind if you focus on them too much. 2 or 3 out over the course of play seems adequate.

3 Jan 13 - Have downgraded from a '10' to '7.5'. Still great but not playing it as much. One problem is that it's not easy to get the cards out if you're playing decks. Trying to get professions out, etc, will mean that you fall behind elsewhere.

22 Oct 14 - Haven't seen this on the table for a long time. Lots of newer games that we prefer. Shipyard, Stone Age, even good ol' Puerto Rico is better. Rate a 5.

Dec 21 - I actually refused to play this the other day. I understand those who love this game as I did once too but you have to play regularly to be good at it and the feeding of the family drives me to distraction when I'm out of practice. Bye, bye, Agricola.

I so very much wanted to like this game. Farming theme? Terrific! Limited resources? Great! But illogical constraints on when I can use those resources ruins it.

Also, the scoring is such that there are not really different strategies to pursue. You need to be decent in almost every aspect and great in a couple. Specialization is not an option.

With some tweaks, I'd probably enjoy it, but I'll just play its superior sibling, Le Havre Fields of Arle, instead.

Update: Taking a chance, I bought Fields of Arle. THAT is the game that I wanted Agricola to be. I also enjoy Caverna and Ora & Labora. But I will never play Agricola again.

The worker placement works well early (as miserable as it may be), limiting resources with players fighting and choking each other, but the pace of the game eventually overloads the board with spaces, resulting in that supposedly key blocking becoming impossible.

The way the game incentivizes collecting some of everything results in a samey experience each play. Hands of cards theoretically change the game, but their random nature results in sets that are sometimes synergistic and sometimes not which makes the game seem to favor players with good draws (which is bad news for a game as long as this one). Drafting or discarding can only help so much when the cards are so unbalanced.

The game is totally different between 2 and multiplayer player counts: In 2, denial makes the game incredibly slow to start, where 3-player games are a bit more friendly, which undermines its player interaction.

Never again

For its time it was an amazing game, but when we take a step back and compare it to more modern designs with shared mechanics it more than shows its age. Don't get me wrong it's still an okay game, maybe good, but not great. Removing my own bias towards what I think is the Golden Eye of boardgames is hard, but realizing I had made that comparison allowed me to accept that it deserves a place in a hall of fame rather than a current top 100 list.

To avoid "ruining" it for other players I rather not discuss the major strategies, but once known it reduces the game into a luck based exercise where players are shoehorned into turn-order jockeying just to make "the move". I am not some kind of boardgame savant, I'm not even that great a player, but I had played enough boardgames to recognize the dominant strategy before finishing Agricola's terrible rulebook.



At first it felt odd to assert that Agricola has somehow gotten worse overtime. The contents and rules have more or less stayed the same so shouldn't the score? It shouldn't. I know it isn't fair to judge Agricola as if it were a modern title, but they're all competing on the same board so we don't have much of a choice. Aside from the major flaw that is the dominant strategy...

The art and iconography is average. I'm willing to concede that beauty is in the eye of the beholder, and perhaps it would be better to say that the art isn't to my taste. But... There is a disconnect between the art of the game and the theme the art is depicting. I'm not asking for photo-realism or a macabre depiction of struggling farmers, but playing this game with a handful of cartoon characters ripped straight out of a discount colouring book tells me art wasn't a concern, they just asked their guy to draw some cartoons and slapped those suckers on. "You don't need great art for a great game" and I would agree with you if it weren't distracting from the overall experience, or if the game had other redeeming qualities. The iconography is at best passable, but the overall presentation is confusing on the cards. Graphics that denote the set or player count requirements are displayed boldly on the center of the card, it wouldn't be unreasonable to assume that information displayed so prominently would be something to be constantly reminded of. Instead anything a player might use in game is comparatively small and pushed to the corners of the cards. I find it funny that the indexing displayed in the center of the card is about as readable as the cost requirements, maybe ever more so since it isn't hyphenated.

Scoring is abstract and disconnected from the game. The game sells you a theme of survival but you'll find yourself fencing in your non existent herd of animals and plowing fields that have no real use to you. The game forces the players to act like some kind of discount compulsive Noah who needs at least one sheep, boar, cow, grain, vegetable and absolutely not a single open space on your property no matter how efficient your engine is. Looking across the table to see a mirror of what you've built is indicative that there are no real choices when playing, we're all doing the same thing, but we have to wait in a queue to do so.

Despite the railroading and the granularity of actions the inability to plan for your turn make this one of the most AP prone games I have ever played. This is a game that asks you to plan ahead but gives you no tools to do so. I love games that force you to adapt to changing circumstances, but that's if the game gives you a way to adapt, think creatively or make flexible plans, Agricola does not. Instead you look at your board and decide what the least shit option is. Thematically action selection is disjointed from common sense, so using theme as a crutch to explain poor mechanics isn't an option, and because of this disconnect from reality teaching this game and remembering rules is a chore.

Sorry Tim, only one person's wife can give birth a turn. Why don't you build an extra room? Oh right, someone is already doing that. I hope you understand that despite having your own property and materials that we've set a limit on new housing developments at one per turn, noise pollution and all that. Hey why not plow a field? Oh. Sorry. Forgot about Susan, can't have two people plowing a day, that'd be against the homeowner association bylaws you agreed to.

The replay value of this game is incredibly poor. The variable setup of this game does nothing to encourage variable strategies. If someone were to tell me that whac-a-mole had a high replay value because the moles appear in semi randomized patterns each game I would assume they've gone mad. Enter turn based whac-a-mole, despite the variable start the players all have the same plan unless they've got...

Broken randomly distributed occupations! Wow exactly what I want from my themeless hour+ long euro... It is hard to believe that anyone can enjoy a euro where at the end of the game you won because you were dealt a stacked hand. Sure you can draft the cards if everyone is an experienced player, but now the game is significantly longer while only slapping an adhesive-bandage on the massive wound that is the wildly imbalanced cards. Oh and you can still win if you're lucky enough to draft a broken combo.

I wasn't expecting to go on a rant so I'll end how I started. Agricola was a fantastic game and it deserves to be in a hall of fame, hopefully we can find a spot for it next to Snakes and Ladders and Monopoly.

I don't see the point of this game, when Caverna is readily available. Caverna is a superior version of this exact game. This game didn't need a reprint, it needed to fade into obscurity. Caverna is the exact same basic game, but fixes my complaints about this game.
Just not my cup of tea.

Having the move you intended to make blocked by another player is of course a natural component of any worker placement game. Here's the thing: at this point, the smartest designers out there have added games to the market in the genre where being blocked from your intended move poses a challenge of adaptation... selecting between one solid option and another, being flexible, and perhaps even altering your long term plans. That's good player interaction. Agricola is not that sort of game. A player blocking your move at the wrong time means your're f*cked. Not "wasted turn", or "Slowed engine" f*cked, as in "You instantly lost the game, eat d*cks" f*cked. There are so many scoring mechanics where missing the mark by one costs an absurd amount of points, the penalties for not feeding your family are so steep and so easy to get stuck with en masse suddenly, so many useful buildings or citizens can be scooped before you can do anything about it, mis-timing or mis-calculating one resource gain can put off your ability to advance for so many turns, that basically it is aborhently easy for one bad turn to cost a dozen points (and in the process, the game). It takes a mechanic meant to make player interaction engaging, and turns it into a game where you suddenly find yourself knee-capped so aggressively it's infuriating and defeat and victory commonly feel arbitrary. There are just so many better games like this out there, don't waste your time on this one.

OK, I think the 7 rating is about where this settles. It's a fun game, and I usually enjoy it, but I'm starting to weary of it as I find the cards to be frustrating as often as they are fun. Also, I think the pressure on wood in the early game is a bit too high, putting a heavy premium on cards that can bootstrap wood (or reeds). Not sure. But the balance doesn't seem right. Usually you know if you have a shot by the second harvest, and usually I know if I've won by that point; the early game is just really tight, and people who get ahead early will win. Also, as I mention, the huge variety implied by the vast number of cards seems deceptive; too many cards are too weak or specialized to be useful very often, and the I and K decks do not seem to stand alone well, so you need at least some E cards to make the game work, which seems to result in seeing the same core cards being played over and over again since they are the most versatile and useful.
---
UPDATE: Well, I've docked my rating a point. I still like Agricola, but I think the initial appearance of variety is deceptive. I think the card mix is too large, too inconsistent, and too surprisingly similar. It's not so much that there are strong cards, but that there are too many weak, useless, or too-highly-specialized cards, and that overall the cards are not helping the theme as much as I thought. I've found myself looking at my cards and seeing only a few legitimate plays and too few really interesting cards. I think the decks needed a round of culling to bring the card count down but the consistency up. It seems that not many games are going to be spoiled for everyone by one player getting great cards and dominating, but having your own game spoiled by a lousy draw occurs with somewhat disappointing frequency.

Also, the early game (Phase I & II) are dominated by getting a food engine going. This is almost entirely contingent on getting cards that enable you to do so in some way. Getting cards that accelerate getting that food engine going seems a huge advantage. Likewise, if you *don't* get that engine going by then, you're done and hardly need to play the rest of the game.
---
After playing some more, this may finally be a game the hypemeisters and I can agree on, more or less. First time through I enjoyed it but it didn't quite suck me in, but more play has improved my opinion. It's thematic enough, and balanced enough to be interesting (unlike similar games, there is almost always something productive to do, instead of having two or three good choices and "the rest"). I think the cards do a good job of allowing the game to have a pretty clean core system, with theme, depth and interest then introduced through the huge variety of cards.

It's still not perfect - the endgame scoring is a little awkward, and the rewards for doing things are not quite lined up with in-game activities, so you end up building worthless fences from time to time just to get a few VPs. There also can be a little lock-up at the end because almost every activity scores points for something, but it's not a smooth curve, there are peaks and plateaus, so towards the end you have to do a little more theme-breaking math than you'd ideally like. It's a little gamey, it would nice if it were better, but it's not a major problem, I think; it's close enough, and for the most part the game lets you play reasonably intuitively.

Definitely keep the player-count to 4 or fewer. 5 is too many, in my opinion - the game becomes too slow.

Agricola is a well-themed, engine-building-efficency-points-salad-maximizer. There is variability in the cards, tension in feeding your family, and frustration via its indirect interaction and limited number of turns. The game has a progressively large number of actions (30+ between WP spots and cards) to choose from and while this may seem to encourage variety and specialization, the points capping and penalties for not doing everything actually works to funnel players down very similar paths. l find the plethora of upfront and increasing information along with the efficiency-point-salad model to be very stressful and AP inducing far beyond my level of enjoyment.

This rating is after my initial play. It could change in the future depending on whether or not my initial fears and concerns turn out to be founded or not. For example:

There are lots of cards and lots of text in very small font on each one of those cards. Because there are so many cards, strong card familiarity is something that would take A LOT of plays to acquire. I see why all of the wooden bits are there but the number of cards in the game seems excessive. It feels like having five boards worth of Puerto Rico buildings - all different and all having a paragraph of text instead of a summary of their use. Yes that many cards would contribute to variety from game to game but when each card requires a paragraph's worth of text to explain its use, the game can very quickly bog down with players reading each card to see what it does. Puerto Rico doesn't suffer from this problem as, after a few plays, you learn what the buildings are and what they do because the same set of buildings is available in each game and you get reminded more frequently how each building works. Race for the Galaxy also doesn't suffer from this problem as it uses a symbol system to explain each card. Thus, once a player is familiar with the symbols, they can quickly tell what a card does.

Also, at it's heart, Agricola seems like a path carving game where, after a few initial turns, you are almost "locked" in to a specific style of play for your cards and resources to interact in the most efficient manner possible and yield the best results. This quasi "locked" feeling kept me from really paying that much attention to the other players when selecting actions. The only thing I cared about was whether or not the action that most benefited me was available when it was my turn. This created the "multi-player solitaire" feeling that many people harp on Euro's about but which I had not truly felt in a Euro before until this game (that's including the usual targets that get indicted by many for being "multi-player solitaire" like Princes of Florence and Race for the Galaxy).

Further, the theme does nothing for me. (I've noticed that farming games in general don't work for me. Hacienda, for example, just isn't exciting to play.)

I just didn't find myself enjoying a lot of the choices, and if you are playing against people who know the game well you will get crushed. You fall behind in this game and catching up is almost impossible.

My rating of a 5 is misleading. If this game were handed in as an assignment, I'd give it an A+. However, that doesn't mean that I like to play it. Because I don't.

There is only one path to victory: (in this order) collect wood, expand house & family ASAP, diversify. There's no need to explore different strategies because they won't work against a player that chooses to follow the one path to victory. And once that player takes the lead, there is no catching up. The game is simply a fierce competition for wood, expansion, diversification. There are many tactics within the strategy, but only one strategy. With a game that has this much going on, this many cards, tokens, tiles, and board space, you'd think that there would be many ways to win. There aren't.

I want to like this game more than I do. I love having to develop and manage the farm, but the game is too much like the setting it models: an environment unforgiving of errors, with an excess of struggle and a lack of fun.

This is an engine building game, but you don't really get to enjoy the engine that you've built. By the time your engine finally starts running, the game is over.

Also, even within the game world a lot of suspension of disbelief is required. If (for one example out of many) two players have ovens for baking bread, they can't both simultaneously bake bread. Yes, sure, it's a game and the rules are there to restrict and guide game play, but it still bothers me. Other players' contrived explanations to help with the suspension of disbelief are equally implausible. "Maybe there's only one oven and what you're gaining is not the oven itself, but permission to use the one oven." Well, cripe, if this actually happened in real life, wouldn't they just build a second oven? Ok, ok, suspension of disbelief. It's just a game.

Yeah, so many complaints. Other than that, it's a really well-designed game.

Solid game, but nothing "wow" in design. Seems like the only big defining thing of the game is that there are a lot of things you need to do, and lots of text-heavy cards, and you don't have enough actions to do everything, so you have to choose and balance trade-offs. Other games have this too, just not taken to such an extreme. But I'd want to have this game if stranded on a desert island with 3-4 other gamers, since the cards give unlimited, if contrived, replay value. I don't understand wtf is so awesome about the cards. They infuse a huge dose of luck into the game, especially since you can't deduce what other people have due to the sheer volume of cards. This game's use of cards is the exact way I hate cards are used for board games (for unnecessary complexity, increasing luck and rewarding experience, and allowing for cheap, no-effort expansions). Also results in frontloaded complexity in having to plan out 14 (!) cards, that makes this game very uneven to play, even when experienced. Biggest mechanical weakness of the game.

Perfect the Family Game (without the cards), which stands up to less than 10 plays (exposing the shallowness of this game), instead of including a ton of cards in the base game and passing it off as an essential part of the game when it really is 3 expansions already packaged in.

I would have preferred it if the design was such that 14 random cards were laid out every game in some common pool, and you could use the Occupation or Minor Improvement action space to draft one of the cards from the pool and play it, after paying its costs. I prefer this pseudo-Family Game version, because the hidden information with the cards just disrupts the well-themed elegance of this game.

Drafting the cards isn't bad either though. It's a good excuse to read cards before the game so I don't have to keep referring back to them during the game.

Listen, I get that this game has a devoted following. But what I can't fathom is why micro-actions to, say, build a fence is fun. I've heard this game drips with theme. Yes, sure, whatever, but it's an explicitly bland theme. Those getting the most enjoyment out of it also seem to be the ones parsing the game's options for super-strategies. This is antithetical to why I play most games; if I want to study a game at length to min-max my tactics, I'll open a Chess book. But then, plodding around, trying not to starve, then losing by 20 points to the player who owns the game isn't much fun either.

I like the sharper edges of the strategy, at least. More games should be comfortable with brutal beats for poor play, rather than handing out points like they're candy at a parade. A shame this fact isn't wrapped in more amusement at those bad beats, as with many others that feature negative scoring.

Agricola deserves some credit for starting a handful of trends in board gaming, or at least popularizing them. They're just not trends I particularly enjoy. So while this version of its ideas is better than many that came after it, that's only saying so much.

The implementation of the theme is poor to a degree I'm worrying about it (only so many fences, just one offspring no matter the number of animals, making food out of wood, stone, whatever, child needs own house...). Certainly a game, asking more for persistence than creativity.

Agricola est un jeu historique qui a contribué, à son époque, à l’essor du jeu de société pour passionnés. En 2025, c'est désormais un jeu daté.

Ce jeu est trop exigeant. Ce n’est vraiment pas drôle. Je dirai même que c’est grave, tellement ce jeu se prend au sérieux. Il me fait aussi peur que les gens dénués de dérision.

Je vous invite à regarder Le Cheval de Turin de Bela Tarr pour voir un équivalent cinématographique à Agricola. Je parle ici d’un film de 2H30, où des gens miséreux mangent des patates dans le noir, dans leur bâtisse isolée du monde, en attendant que l’hiver passe.

Pour des soucis de cohérence avec la rudesse de l’épreuve que traversent les ouvriers d’Agricola, je vais les renommer des « condamnés » aux travaux forcés. Aller comprendre pourquoi on s’inflige ça, mais il va falloir aller chercher de très nombreuses fois des moyens de nourrir nos condamnés. Sous un prétexte simulationniste, on passe son temps à faire des actions stériles pour trouver de la nourriture. On fait tellement souvent ça, qu’à la fin, on ne construit rien d’intéressant. C’est tendu, non pas parce que les joueurs se disputent les ressources, mais parce que le jeu ne veut rien donner aux joueurs !

De plus, il y a des aménagements qui sont tellement nuls qu’ils ne rentrent dans aucune stratégie viable. Ce sont juste des pièges à débutants, créés pour les mettre à genoux, leur faire baisser la tête et leur faire comprendre l’humilité.

Épargnez-vous ce chemin de croix. Il existe plein d’autres jeux complexes qui proposent une expérience heureuse, où la pose d’ouvriers offre des récompenses généreuses et non pas de pingres sacrifices de la part du jeu. Essayez Les Châteaux de Bourgogne, Underwater Cities ou Beyond the Sun.

Agricola is a classic in the worker placement genre, being one of the first games to really kick the genre off. While it's clear to see where following games took inspiration, it's also clear how the design is a bit dated in some ways compared to more modern takes. First of all, the game is quite complex compared to its successors, which retain the core type of gameplay while managing to be more approachable. Relatedly, the theme is rather dry and not something that will excite many people, even if it does fit well enough with the mechanics, while more modern games in the genre like Everdell and Dune:Imperium are far more likely to grab players (Agricola's art being subpar also doesn't help). Gameplay wise, Agricola is also comparatively harsh: you'll be stuck on just two actions per turn for a while, and even once the option of having kids opens up there's a serious cost to get them in play, along with an extra mouth to feed adding to the real struggle to have enough food when harvest comes around while doing what you want to (way way harder than something like Stone Age, even). Each resource is generally limited to one action space, i.e. only one person can grab it per turn, so the "take that" element when someone beats you to an action you want to take can be very painful as there's not usually a different way to accomplish the same thing. Agricola lives up to its setting of being a struggling farmer getting by, and while I probably would want to play it again at some point and can appreciate its complexity to some extent, I think for new players especially but also just myself that I would rather play a more approachable (and enjoyable, due to being less harsh and having stronger progression over the course of the game) worker placement game like Everdell instead.

Truly gave me the angst of "you want to do everything, but you cant" that is exemplified in so many great games. I always think of the fond nostalgia I have with Agricola, but I never want to pull this thing off the shelf given that it is so big, so long and ultimately not very interesting once you realize you're just going for the same core strategy of maximizing workers every game.

Agricola is a worker placement game that takes 14 rounds. Each round has 3 phases. These rounds are grouped into 6 stages. Each stage will end with a special 4th harvest phase where you get to harvest any grain or vegetables you’ve grown, feed your family, and breed animals. You begin as a couple of farmers in a little house - so 2 workers. You’ll be placing workers on a space to take the action of that space. There are accumulation spaces that will continue to fill up with goods each round. A space of this type that goes unused will become more and more appealing as the goods build up over time. A new action space is revealed each round for more options, but this game does use action blocking so once a player puts a worker on an action space - no one else can use that action until the next round.

You’ll be growing your farm, home, and family. More family means extra workers for more actions, but you have to keep them fed or you’ll start gaining beggar cards worth negative VP. There are also a ton of cards for improvements and occupations that provide more abilities and scoring. As with any game with so many cards, there ends up being a bit of luck for getting good combinations that work well for what you’re doing - and some are clearly better than others.

The game is tight and encourages you to be flexible. Someone will most likely be blocking what you want to do, so it is good to always have a backup plan. Making the best of whatever cards you draw is part of the game. Ensuring you keep your growing family fed adds a bit to the tension, but also feels tedious. Always getting workers as quickly as possible is just repetitive but necessary. Despite the large number of cards which should add variety, every game feels basically the same to me. I think it is mostly designed well - but it is just boring.

Agricola is a classic. It's a game I appreciate and would come back to play once in a while, but the lack of variability makes each experience feel samey. Feeding the workers can be quite tiresome and going for extra workers is basicly a non-brainer.

A classic game that I hadn't played until 2025. Shocking, I know.

And I can see why it's well-liked and formative for many modern Euro gamers. The tight worker placement and economic considerations make you really squeeze out every single victory point. And starting out in essentially a negative position seems to be something that Rosenberg does quite often. I've actually played A Feast for Odin before, as well as a couple of his other games, so I did have something of an insight into what would be in this game.

I do appreciate having a lot of runway over the course of the game to actually make some progress. That does help you have something of a feeling of breaking through late in the game when you FINALLY accomplish something of value. But the scores are fairly low. Some good choices over which worker spots to take, especially as they get better with more resources dumping on them each round.

We also played with the Farmers of the Moor expansion, and that did add extra considerations with horses, heating and some extra cards. It seemed to add a reasonable extra cognitive layer to an already heavy-ish game.

Do I like this game better than Feast? Probably not. I think that game sings in many ways that shows the evolution of Rosenberg as a designer, whereas this was his original strong entry. And I think I expected that A Feast for Odin would be a long game; I didn't expect that to be the case for Agricola. It might just be a one-off, but it was pretty long. Still, besides the length of game and me not really giving a crap about the theme, art or presentation, I do respect the mechanics.

Everything is a struggle, and that does at least mechanically evoke something of the struggle of putting together this functioning farm.

Agricola gets right what most other worker placement games get wrong. Rather than attempting to make the worker placement mechanic itself interesting, Agricola uses vanilla worker placement on top of a ruthlessly tight game engine. Each harvest serves as a reminder of how much you wish you could do and how far behind that you actually are. The only things that relax the game engine are the Occupation and Minor Improvement cards, whose synergies/efficiencies serve as the primary exploration space for the game.

While Agricola is primarily a tight rope walk of efficiency (which I find less interesting than shared incentives), there is an undeniable variety each game when drafting your hand of 14 cards. And given how quickly it plays, you can reasonably get enough reps in to explore that variety.

This was the second hobby game I ever bought. Once I realized there were more games like Catan out there, I found Boardgamegeek and went out and bought the number one ranked game. At the time that was Agricola. Wow - my family was NOT prepared from the step up from Catan to Agricola! But I stuck with it, played some solo games, and eventually wore everyone down to play the full game. It instantly became my favorite game of all time (out of the 4 or so that I had played...). It stayed that way for a few years until overtaken by my current #1 in 2013.

Honestly, what's not to like about this game? The fact that it is difficult to feed your family? Stressful when someone takes that action that thwarts your plans? OR maybe because it is really really hard to do at least a little bit of everything to avoid losing too many points? Yes these are the knocks against this game. But for me, these are the reasons i LOVE the game!

Yes, Caverna came out. It is a looser game with many more options in many ways, and it's easier to feed people. But the tightness of Agricola is what I appreciate most - I feed off of the urgency to feed my family. Caverna has a bunch of rooms, but they are static. Agricola has a crap-ton of cards that change every single game. Note: ALWAYS play with a starting draft of cards, as this lessens the possibility that you'll get dealt a dud hand.

Caverna is a really good game. Agricola is better. So much so that I don't even consider Caverna anymore, and it has left my top 100 and collection.
What I love most about this game is the competitiveness. Actions are simple but you have to think twice about what you want to do, what others want to do and how to block them

Wow, is this good. A classic for a reason. Such a tight design: every choice is critical and brutal. You're worried about everything you need to do in a very limited time frame, but also everyone else is snatching the same resources, and how am I gonna feed all these people?!

Rating based on multiplayer. For solo play more like 8 - Still great! Although I didn't find that I wanted to play it more than a few times at a stretch. Some more recent games have improved on adding things like factions (or spirits, companies, etc.) to provide more replayability by creating a slightly different experience every time. Here you have project cards to give you some direction, but they don't feel like they drive your play as much. I should try out an AI opponent variant.

It's quite a different game with other players than solo. Solo is just an efficiency game, it's so much more complex with other players. Suddenly you have competition and resource scarcity, and who goes first matters (but brilliantly, you can spend a precious action in this round to claim a critical first choice in the next). A point in its favor is that beefing up your solo experience doesn't make it so you can't play with others. With some games, playing too much on your own means you've developed skill and experience and won't be a good match with new players anymore. Not here.

Agricola is the magnum opus of Rosenberg's work and perhaps the board gaming hobby. The worker placement mechanic is simple but the depth materializes from the intricate and brutal game engine that Agricola presents. Players must balance obtaining resources to build out their farm while establishing a food engine that can sustain them over the six harsh harvests throughout the game. A myriad of occupations and minor improvements help create more elaborate synergies and scoring opportunities, unlocking an unfathomable amount of replayability which ensures each play to be unique. Some may find Agricola's tight gameplay to be too burdensome but for others it's the reason this masterpiece hits the table time and time again.

Phenomenal game, just brilliant. I still think that Agricola is Uwe Rosenberg's magnum opus. And it just keeps getting better with each subsequent play (especially with the Farmers of the Moor and Gamers' Deck expansions added). I love the tightness of this design and the interrelation between the theme and the mechanics - everything is intuitive and makes perfect sense. The best thing about this game is the challenge of managing scarce resources and figuring out the most effective ways of using the cards in your hand. This puzzle is just a fascinating, brain-burning delight. But keep in mind that this is a "I wonder if I can do this better, quicker and more efficiently next time" type of game. Optimization is the heart of Agricola, so if you don't like designs like that, you probably won't enjoy this one.

By the way, Agricola works exceptionally well as a solo game! It's a really challenging puzzle.

The only drawback I can think of is the constant need for repleneshing goods - this gets a bit too fiddly, especially late game.

/update: my plays are split between the Revised and the original editions (depending which one I pick for the game night).

After expanding the Revised Edition with Artifex + Bubulcus decks and Farmers of the Moor I can finally say that this is the version to get at this moment due to better availability, the card pool became big enough and I trust that the selected cards are balanced and polished. I will never get rid of my old version though, it's still absolutely wonderful and I love many of the cards that are missing in the new one (especially the G-deck). But if you don't own Agricola yet and want to get into it, I guess it's better to get the Revised stuff. Honestly though, you can't go wrong with either edition (I love the old pool of cards). This game is a work of art.
